Pythagorean.description: Fixed, sequential mapping of English alphabet; A=1, B=2, ..., Z=26; then reduced to single digit or master number
Pythagorean.origin: Ancient Greece, attributed to Pythagoras (c. 570-495 BCE)
characteristics: Widely used in United States and Europe

Chaldean.description: Non-sequential, vibration-based mapping; focuses on sound vibrations of letters; uses numbers 1-8 (excludes sacred 9)
characteristics: Based on mystical beliefs concerning sound vibrations
Emphasizes compound numbers before full reduction
Focuses on external influences, fate, and karmic patterns
Preferred in India and Middle East for advanced readings
Chaldean.note: Chaldean system does not use number 9; certain letters share the same value based on sound vibration principles

Kabbalah.description: Based on Hebrew alphabet; uses gematria (assigning numerical values to Hebrew letters); distinguishes between vowel and consonant values
Kabbalah.origin: Jewish Mysticism, originating with the Sefer Yetzirah
characteristics: Focuses on spiritual and divine meanings
Uses 22 letters of Hebrew alphabet with specific numerical values

mappings.Hebrew System: Based on 22-letter Hebrew alphabet with values: Aleph=1, Bet=2, Gimel=3, Dalet=4, He=5, Vav=6, Zayin=7, Het=8, Tet=9, Yod=10, Kaf=20, Lamed=30, Mem=40, Nun=50, Samekh=60, Ayin=70, Pe=80, Tsade=90, Qof=100, Resh=200, Shin=300, Tav=400
mappings.Vowel-Consonant: Vowels represent soul qualities, consonants represent personality traits

Kabbalah.note: Kabbalah numerology requires Hebrew names or transliteration; does not use standard English alphabet mapping

Chinese.description: Phonetic-based system; meaning determined by pronunciation in Mandarin or Cantonese
characteristics: Meaning based on sound of number's pronunciation
Even numbers generally favored over odd numbers
